title: U.S. Stocks Waver After Evergrande Payment Deadline Passes; Bitcoin prices fall after China's central bank declares all cryptocurrency-related transactions illegal
text:
Markets have been whipsawed this week by fears that the possible collapse of Evergrande could spill over into global markets and add to an already darkening outlook for global growth. Investors who own Evergrande's U.S. dollar bonds hadn't received an interest payment by a Thursday deadline.

"It is one of the largest companies in the second-largest economy in the world and if something pulls down Chinese growth it is going to pull down global growth," said Seema Shah, chief strategist at Principal Global Investors.

The company's shares fell 11.6% Friday in Hong Kong, and are down more than 84% this year.

Cryptocurrency prices fell after China's central bank declared all cryptocurrency-related transactions illegal. Bitcoin fell nearly 7% from its 5 p.m. ET level Thursday to about $41,594, according to CoinDesk. Ether slumped nearly 10%. Shares of cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase Global fell 1.7% in morning trading.

Among individual stocks, Meredith Corp. surged 29% after The Wall Street Journal reported that the People Magazine publisher was in talks to be acquired by Barry Diller's IAC/InterActiveCorp.

Shares of Nike tumbled 6.4% after the sportswear giant lowered revenue guidance, citing supply-chain disruptions in Asia.

Government bond yields have climbed this week after several central banks—including the Federal Reserve—signaled they were on the path toward removing pandemic-era stimulus measures. The yield on the benchmark 10-Year U.S. Treasury note rose to 1.449% on Friday, from 1.408% on Thursday. Bond yields and prices move in opposite directions.

Fed Chairman Jerome Powell is set to speak at a virtual event at 10 a.m. ET Friday, alongside other central bank officials.

Investors are also awaiting new home sales data, which are set to be released at 10 a.m. The figures are expected to show sales grew at a faster rate in August than in July.

Overseas, the pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 fell 0.8%. In Asia, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 1.3%, while the Shanghai Composite Index weakened 0.8%.
